channel.title: 40th anniversary of the moon landing
channel.description:
i just saw the stupid little google image and it made me think about the whole is it real or not thing, so im gonna ask you, was it real or not? and put your reason why.
EDIT-i think maybe. cause i saw the mythbusters episode. and now i see some pictures that make me think no.

item.title: 40th anniversary of the moon landing
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

There are no stars on the background of photo’s on the moon, because of light exposure. The moon reflects a lot of light, so if your shutter is open too long the photo’s are ruined. I doubt you can make a picture of stars when it’s dark outside, but you are in a snowy area and the moon is bright.

Read full topic

item.title: 40th anniversary of the moon landing
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

The early Apollo missions scouted the areas where the LLM’s took place, so they knew where the Reflectors were placed. Also, the recent photographs from the moon, showing the forms of the landing sites also help prove that.

The retro-reflectors had to be installed by the way. Heavy pieces that couldn’t possibly be installed with the technology used then. Especially when the Firmware behind the computers on the Lunar Lander weren’t even capable of processing all the data themselves during the landing process, so how could they be expected to have enough AI to actually travel on the moon, place the reflectors there, and then open them.

Don’t say they could’ve done it later on. Because after they were installed they were most likely used when the technology caught up with the idea. Still before the time of Modern Computers.

EDIT: I take back what I said, I recall the Lunokhod rover missions from the Soviets. Which did in fact place reflectors on the moon, and it took place in 1970.

Read full topic

item.title: 40th anniversary of the moon landing
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Elijah, post:25, topic:290057”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=383423.msg2879105#msg2879105 date=1248217272]

laser proves that something manmade went to the moon, you could put that reflector on a rover and just dump it there.

i meant the whole crop-circle-aliens-did-it conspiracy.

mind-control is not equal to mind-influencing. The conspiracy theory is that the government can control your mind.

Only so long the source that telling you that the laser hit the reflector and back again are telling the truth, it proves that it is a reflector there.

so you’re basically asking me to believe that the entire scientific establishment is lying.

goatee, yeah fine, but I think those mind-control conspiracy theorists mean mind-control in the sense someone can make you pick up a knife and stab yourself, not just the statistical way that advertising and propaganda work.

No, I just says that if there was an conspiracy the laser won’t tell anything since NASA who fake the moon-landing was also control of the laser that “prove” there was an moon-landing.

I believe in Science, only time you should doubt the fact science give you is when the scientist(Or their employer) may have something to hide.
[/quote]

Scientists across the Earth, not associated to NASA, for example the Soviets. Can all fire their lasers at the reflectors. So it’s not just NASA.[/quote]
I don’t doubt the facts, I just said that the hitting the reflectors in Mythbusters did not prove anything.
How do they know where to hit?
Also it does not prove that humans placed the reflector there.

Read full topic

so you’re basically asking me to believe that the entire scientific establishment is lying.

goatee, yeah fine, but I think those mind-control conspiracy theorists mean mind-control in the sense someone can make you pick up a knife and stab yourself, not just the statistical way that advertising and propaganda work.
[/quote]
No, I just says that if there was an conspiracy the laser won’t tell anything since NASA who fake the moon-landing was also control of the laser that “prove” there was an moon-landing.

I believe in Science, only time you should doubt the fact science give you is when the scientist(Or their employer) may have something to hide.[/quote]

Scientists across the Earth, not associated to NASA, for example the Soviets. Can all fire their lasers at the reflectors. So it’s not just NASA.

item.dc:creator: @goatee goatee
item.description:

i meant the whole crop-circle-aliens-did-it conspiracy.

mind-control is not equal to mind-influencing. The conspiracy theory is that the government can control your mind.

Only so long the source that telling you that the laser hit the reflector and back again are telling the truth, it proves that it is a reflector there.
[/quote]

so you’re basically asking me to believe that the entire scientific establishment is lying.

goatee, yeah fine, but I think those mind-control conspiracy theorists mean mind-control in the sense someone can make you pick up a knife and stab yourself, not just the statistical way that advertising and propaganda work.[/quote]

You could argue that propaganda could be used to make people commit suicide. A major hype about the end of the world through the media could trigger a large number of suicides, even if it were all just a lie. But I see your point, the government does not have devices or some kind of poisonous gas that will make you do whatever they want. There is always free will.

The laser proved quite a bit. It proved Men had landed on the moon, and had placed Retro-reflectors so that scientists could monitor the moon.

item.title: 40th anniversary of the moon landing
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Elijah:

As stated earlier, the Mythbusters pretty much proved we landed on the moon. Especially with their last experiment, where they shot lasers at the moon, and the retro reflectors reflected the light back.

The laser does not prove anything, but they proved all the things that crazy people said was faked.
They would never send people to the moon again if it was fake, there is a little chance that the first moon-landing was fake(Made a fake moonlanding to be faster than the Russians), but there is no doubt that USA went to the moon for real.

Read full topic

item.title: 40th anniversary of the moon landing
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

Once again, their earlier statement goes against what you just said. The sun is closer than the star Proxima Centauri, which this scene was in direct light of the sun, causing the exposure of the photograph to not show some of the stars. This is basic photography.

As stated earlier, the Mythbusters pretty much proved we landed on the moon. Especially with their last experiment, where they shot lasers at the moon, and the retro reflectors reflected the light back.

conspiracies are fucking stupid

EDIT:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Examination_of_Apollo_Moon_photographs

Read full topic

item.title: 40th anniversary of the moon landing
item.dc:creator: @TLitten TLitten
item.description:
@TLitten wrote:

maybe its just me but daytime would have a effect, but since your already in space it should help shouldnt it?

there is a star called Proxima Centauri- its a red dwarf star with a apparent magnitude of m-11(brightness). this star can be seen 4.2 lightyears away. now, a “star” has a small m-6, but is 100 times brighter than proxima. now, since the moon is already 238855 miles away from earth. figuring to be 384400 kilometers. but what im getting at, is i guess you could say the moon is “closer” or whatever, maybe its bullshit, but since the moon could be 23885 miles closer to the stars, and with no atmosphere to block, and these stars are buring 100,000 degrees farenheight. the core temp sometimes can be a huge 200,000,000. thats 200 million. thats 175 million more degrees than the sun (25 million-sun) these stars are burning so bright, i mean havent you ever seen stars during the day sometimes? it rarely happens but i have. so all that shouldnt affect it, the moon is way the hell out there, along with the stars, maybe its just me, but thanks for replying, i wanted kind of a small argument lol, thanks

**this whole paragraph probably made no sense what so ever lol, i tend to ramble…

the latter is the most likely reason because even at night time in a city you cant see the stars its the same principal here

that is because earth has an atmosphere. the moon doesnt.

Read full topic

item.title: 40th anniversary of the moon landing
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:8, topic:290057”][quote author=TLitten link=topic=383423.msg2878504#msg2878504 date=1248192798]

then explain the image…since there is no atmosphere on the moon you should be able to see millions of stars…but in this picture it is like a big black void behind them.

**image taken from- http://www.howstuffworks.com
[/quote]

Do you really think if they were going to stage this, they would forget to add stars?

There’s several logical explanations. There isn’t enough light given off the stars and it was taken with a short exposure time. Try it, take a picture at night with a short exposure time and a flash. Tell me if you see stars in the photo.

It is also day-time on the moon in this photo. It’s too bright to see the stars. [/quote]
the latter is the most likely reason because even at night time in a city you cant see the stars its the same principal here

Read full topic

**image taken from- http://www.howstuffworks.com[/quote]

Do you really think if they were going to stage this, they would forget to add stars?

There’s several logical explanations. There isn’t enough light given off the stars and it was taken with a short exposure time. Try it, take a picture at night with a short exposure time and a flash. Tell me if you see stars in the photo.

It is also day-time on the moon in this photo. It’s too bright to see the stars.
